reviewText:
Stealing Valve's graphical assets and then submitting your game with them inside is a next level strat.

Update: My game got reset. That $0.99 I paid for coins (purely for this review's sake) is now gone and so are the coins and everything I spent them on. I reported this game to Steam for fraud. I suggest you all do the same.

Poor graphics, poor audio assets, consistently poor translation and lag on a computer that is dozens of times powerful enough to run a game with this caliber aren't enough to entirely condemn this game. The gameplay can work (maybe a bit better on a touch screen) and it is moderately satisfying to play, but some very poor decisions destine this game for deletion.

Spartans vs Zombies Defense is comparable to Battle Cats. You buy units and upgrades to defend your castle gate from waves of enemies and push forward to destroy their spawn. You can use items and cast abilities to aid your units or to harm the enemy. There are enough mechanics and upgrades to keep the game playble, perhaps all the way through the 60 waves provided.

The flaw with this game is that it is free to play with in-game transactions. They are not balanced. It begins to become horribly tedious to beat wave 10 without them and I imagine that it would take months of straight, active gameplay to get to wave 60 without them. The enemy/leveling system progresses in a way where they are necessary, and that's just cynical. The game would be much better if it had no microtransactions, had a balanced leveling system, and cost $2.50. It probably would have made a lot more money, too (I feel dirty for spending $0.99 to test the coins for the sake of this review).

While I did say that this game had bad graphics, that can't even begin to describe just how bad they are. The icons for the castables are plagarized from DotA 2. I did not immediately realize that Magic Arrow was a colorized Starstorm (Mirana) icon or that Protection was a hue-shifted Time Walk (Faceless Void) icon, but the second that I unlocked Fiery Souls, I recognized it as the Shadowraze (Shadow Fiend) icon. I'm not sure if Wild Attack was stolen as well, but it is difficult to imagine otherwise. I'm certain that other assets were stolen as well - I doubt that the creators asked Gerard Butler or Warner Brothers for permission to slap his face on Leonidas, or on the game's banner, for that matter. I wish YFC luck on their legal endeavors.

Spartans Vs Zombies Defense is a free casual defense game with microtransactions.
Sparta is under attack from zombies and it is the task of King Leonidas and his soldiers to stop them.
The gameplay is very simple. It consists of a series of waves, which goes up until wave 60, with enemies attacking from the right side of the screen. The enemies are moving to the left side and trying to overrun your castle. The player moves Leonidas left and right with his mouse and when Leonidas and an enemy meet they start fighting. The aim is to defeat all enemies before they destroy the castle or kill Leonidas. The player accumulates silver over time which can be used to hire units to help defend the castle. They will move forward automatically to fight. Besides of the regular mode you can also play some endless mode (you have to unlock them by completing wave 60), it is the same like the regular mode but instead of waves you will have a timer.
The game is really boring, each wave plays like the wave before. After the first few waves everything the game has to offer has already been seen. There are microtransactions which let the player purchase coins with real money.
The game has the name Spartans Vs Zombies" Defense but the enemies are all skeletons and not zombies.
Another poor aspect is that every complete sentence in the game is grammatically incorrect.
It could be possible that Spartans Vs Zombies Defense could be removed very soon from the store due to copyright infringement. Besides of the look of Leonidas from the movie 300

reviewText:
The first time I saw the name of this game, ‚ÄúSpartan vs Zombie defense,‚Äù I got excited as I love defense style games thanks to custom defenses in Warcraft. But I digress, the game itself has many good and bad points and I‚Äôll explain them soon.

Firstly before I do get into the points, I want to point out that after you‚Äôve played a few rounds or even look at the pictures advertising the game on Steam... That the game is named wrongly. They call it Spartans VS Zombies... When in fact the game actually uses Skeleton sprites and not Zombies... Like they could be Zombies but to me well, no, just no.

Now onto the Positives and Negatives.

Positives:

‚ô¶ Unlockable Modes,
‚ô¶ Unlockable Spells,Units, Items and Upgrades etc
‚ô¶ Easy but time consuming Achievements
‚ô¶ Easy Concept
‚ô¶ Great UI
‚ô¶ Awesome Range of Units to Verse
‚ô¶ Awesome Character, Army, Castle and Item Skill upgrade menu
‚ô¶ Micro-transactions are optional and doesn't force you to buy anything
‚ô¶ Spells can level up (Casting them without purchasing upgrades for them)
‚ô¶ Fast loading between rounds
‚ô¶ Endless Modes are a good concept (However, implemented wrongly)

Negatives:

‚ô¶ Graphics (Most of the graphics and sounds are copyright from 300 or the likes)
‚ô¶ Can be pay to win (This would be a once off Micro transaction of $25, Really expensive for a Micro transaction)
‚ô¶ Minimal Options (Only music and sound check boxes with no control setup, resolution, graphics etc)
‚ô¶ Poor Mobile Device Port (Says, touchscreen to move, tap to summon etc)
‚ô¶ Alt+Tab doesn't take you to desktop (It pauses the game on screen)
‚ô¶ Pressing ESC in game gives you the option to quit only (No way back to main menu, you have to click a pause icon and then hit quit to get to main menu again)
‚ô¶ Point & Click but not advertised as a Point & Click
‚ô¶ Micro-transactions (Makes the already simple and pointless game pay to win)
‚ô¶ No way to map controls to A and D or Left and Right arrows to move (Must use Mouse whole game)
‚ô¶ No way to keybind units or spells (Again really annoying as you have to click everything)
‚ô¶ Hardly get any coins per game, compared to buying them through micro-transaction option
‚ô¶ Game seems really slow paced
‚ô¶ No Steam Trading Cards (Could have easily included some)
‚ô¶ Repetitive after about the 10th round (Also if you don't buy Micro transaction gold for upgrades, the levels are really repetitive due to having to do the same one over and over again to get enough gold to upgrade enough to be able to beat that level)
‚ô¶ No incentive to replay the campaign (There is harder difficulty unlocked for campaign once you beat the 60 waves, but why re-do campaign again when you can do endless?)
‚ô¶ Endless mode has no Global Steam Highscores
‚ô¶ Clicking and Moving can lag sometimes and not register
‚ô¶ Unbalanced units (A group of enemy's could barely hurt me whilst one Archer could kill me in a few shots and all I needed was Calvary upgraded to win.)
‚ô¶ Upgrade menu for units on Towers has wrong upgrade symbol when purchasing (Tells me I'm upgrading the units health when they can't die or be attack)
‚ô¶ Seems way too easy (Get to a point where you out way the enemies in strength hands down and never lose)
‚ô¶ Items and Potions seem pointless outside of Endless Mode (Can easily win most levels without using or buying any, they'd just speed things up)
‚ô¶ If you get stuck on a later level you pretty much have to buy micro-transaction gold to pass (This is because you get no gold for dying, only what you've picked up during the wave, I died numerous times on wave 60 and things cost over 20k to upgrade...)
‚ô¶ No Story or Cutscenes (Other than the lame 5 second one at the start)
‚ô¶ Nothing happens when beating the final wave (Taken to main menu and told campaign just got harder in difficulty)
‚ô¶ No way to tell how long you've been in endless mode after you've died

Overall, the game is free, poorly ported from Mobile as it acts and talks as though you are playing on a mobile device... it still runs 100% smoothly, is fun for about the first 5 to 10 rounds in campaign and then it became really boring and repetitive. Plus you know a game is bad if they call it a Zombie Defense and not have any Zombies in it... Though on another point, the laggyness of moving, the small amount of gold received to upgrade and the unbalanced units start to get to you. Eventually, if you make it to the end of the first playthrough of the campaign, you‚Äôll unlock endless modes. These aren‚Äôt even worth unlocking as there is no highscores to compare how well you‚Äôve done even with yourself little own your friends, the world or Steam Users. I guess I‚Äôm glad this is free as I‚Äôd not recommend this to anyone, not even to play it on a phone/tablet where it should have stayed.

Also why does this game have soo much copyrighted material in it that it doesn‚Äôt have licenses for and yet asks you to pay for micro-transactions? To me this game is one big flop with a law suit waiting to happen.

On another note, answer me this... Why would anyone pay for a game that you can‚Äôt verse others or even have a global highscore? Seems pointless if you can‚Äôt show off what you‚Äôve paid for in some way to someone.

Final Rating: If you are extremely bored, want to laugh at poor development and or cringe at what could have been a good game, then this is for you!

reviewText:
I am not sure why this game gets so much hate. It is, as others have said, a clone of Army of Darkness Defence (which isn't available on PC), and is a mobile port. The main complaint people have is that It may use assets from other games/movies, but that's for the owner's of those assets to decide. I actually liked the game quite a bit, though it is repetitive, and not very deep. I liked Army of Darkness Defense, and this is basically the same game. And it is free.

The game is basically a side scrolling action/strategy game. Your hero character has to defend your castle against waves of enemies. In each level you have to balance buying upgrades for your tower (just increased gold production) with buying units to help you defend against the enemy waves. Between levels you can spend earnee gold on upgrades to your hero, units, castle, or spells. The upgrades have a huge effect on how tough you are, until they cap out at level 10. If you die during a level, you keep the gold you earned during that level, but don't get the win bonus. If the levels are too hard, a few tries is usually enough to earn the gold needed to upgrade something and make the level easier. I made it to level 40 with just a couple deaths, but then the game got quite tough. The startegy in the game is in deciding which units to upgrade, and which units to buy (and when to buy them) during each level. It's not real deep, but I quite enjoyed it.

The game is free to play. You can buy gold in the game with real money, but I can't imagine why you would want or need to. I earned gold plenty fast enough to make it to level 40 without much trouble, though the game started getting pretty tough after that, mainly because I maxed out the stats on my favorite units. I'll have to start diversiying my unit unage more, and play a bit smarter, if I am going to actually beat the game. I plan to play it more and try to beat it. I think there are 60 levels in the game (the top achievement is for beating 60 levels). and at some point you unlock some endless modes, but I haven't unlocked them yet.

My conclusion: It's a mobile port with repetitive gameplay, but also quite a lot of fun.

One small grumble - there is no control for sound volume. I could turn the music off, but turning the sound off didn't work.

reviewText:
Downvote simulator 2015 (Recommend a game that is heavily unpopular!)

Once you get past the horrid presentation the game itself is fine. It rips off other games in its genre without messing up what makes them fun to play, unlike Dungeon of the Endless.

I can critique the stolen art assests, ripped off music or the god awful translation all I want but the bottom line is this, you have to pay to get your game on steam even if your game is free. Clearly enough people are spending money within the games cash shop to allow this game to not only continue to exist but have even made it this far in the first place.
This game isn't at fault, you are if you are spending money in its cash shop.
And you will, won't you, you filthy casual!

You start out as all these games do, extremely powerful. You lead Leonidas ripped from the movie 300 complete with ripped soundbytes against a mindless zerg army of SKELETONS (not a zombie in sight, by the way) and as all these types of games go you click to send out your units who will march to the other end of the screen mindlessly until they are dead or you destroy the enemy portal. Game over occours when you lose your portal.

As usual with these kind of games you will rapidly start fighting against armies you have no chance against but if you need a little help...That's right, just open your wallet, thats a good goy!
As far as games go I really hate to admit it but I have played worse than this.

The game is typical Tower Defense fanfare. You need to not let your tower get smashed while trying to kill the enemy. You have the usual array of tanky swordsmen, weakling archers who attack from a safe distance, pikemen who oddly hit hard but are as squishy as archers, calvary who are tanky as swordsmen but move fast and hit twice as hard and so on and so forth, balance is a bit of an issue.

The enemy army progresses faster than you do coming at you both with absurd numbers and stronger units than you have access too but your ace in the hole is Leonidas whom has access to spells and abilities that can turn a fight to your advantage...If he has enough mana to do so. Which surprisingly, he often does despite the cash shop selling mana potions.

On that note the cash shop is there and the game is quite 'challenging' (read: enemy swarm) but I made it pretty far just fine without ever feeling like I hit the infamous cash wall*" so despite the really poor presentation the game is playable and as far as tower defense games go
